data.title: Entertainment Live: Justin Bieber and Rihanna to headline V Festival
data.meta_description: V 2016 unveils pop-heavy line-up; UK's Eurovision hopefuls announced plus more arts, entertainment and media.
data.text:
Chicago to hold FerrisFest marking 30th anniversary of movie

If you can remember this film in cinemas, or it's a dearly beheld movie from your childhood, then we are sorry to remind you of your age.

Chicago is to hold an event later this year called FerrisFest, marking the 30th anniversary of the cult movie Ferris Bueller's Day Off.

There will be a screening of John Hughes' 1986 film - in which a rebellious teenager skives off school to go on a whirlwind tour of the Windy City - and several events attended by stars of the film.

There is even a recreation of Ferris's bedroom (below).

The festival runs from 20-22 May.

Altogether now.... "Bueller.... Bueller... Bueller..."

Damning new report finds "inclusion crisis" in Hollywood

APCopyright: AP

A new study has suggested Hollywood has an "epidemic of invisibility" for women, minorities and LGBT people.

The paper by the University of Southern California stated the film industry has an "inclusion crisis" from CEOs to minor characters.

"Overall, the landscape of media content is still largely whitewashed," it said.

It comes just days ahead of the Oscars, criticised over the lack of diversity in its award nominations.

Read more.

Tate to host Hockney retrospective

BBCCopyright: BBC

Here's some big news for all you Hockney-philes out there, the Tate has announced it will host a retrospective exhibition of the works of artist David Hockney.

The exhibition, which opens in February 2017 for three months, "will celebrate Hockney’s achievement in painting, drawing, print, photography and video," a press release said.

Overseas Hockney fans need not worry about missing it, as the exhibition will travel to Paris and New York after it closes in London.

Quote Message: It has been a pleasure to revisit works I made decades ago, including some of my earliest paintings. Many of them seem like old friends to me now. We’re looking back over a lifetime with this exhibition, and I hope, like me, people will enjoy seeing how the roots of my new and recent work can be seen in the developments over the years. from David Hockney

It has been a pleasure to revisit works I made decades ago, including some of my earliest paintings. Many of them seem like old friends to me now. We’re looking back over a lifetime with this exhibition, and I hope, like me, people will enjoy seeing how the roots of my new and recent work can be seen in the developments over the years.

David Hockney

Paramore's Hayley Williams gets married

Diminutive Paramore singer Hayley Williams has married her long-term partner, New Found Glory guitarist Chad Gilbert, in Nashville.

What was their first dance we wonder?

Read more.

Getty ImagesCopyright: Getty Images

Could New Day signal a new dawn for newspapers?

PACopyright: PA

With declining circulations and the recent closure of a national print title, you might think now wouldn't be the best time to consider launching a newspaper.

But that doesn't seem to be putting off the Daily Mirror's publisher Trinity Mirror. The company is set to print its first edition of The New Day next Monday (29 Feb).

It's going to cost 50p and chief executive Simon Fox says he hopes it will "arrest the decline" in newspaper readership.

It's the second new print title to launch in the last decade. The i paper - from the same team behind The Independent - began life in 2010 and rapidly became more popular than its big sister paper. But launching a newspaper in the internet age is a tricky business, which The New Day's editor Alison Philips is all too aware of. She spoke to BBC Radio 4 this morning

Read more.

Quote Message: "There has been a massive nuclear bomb gone off in the media world with the advent of the internet, and we have created a newspaper which reflects that and understands that. So, whilst now there is a breaking story and people have got news alerts on their phones all the time, what they quite often want is a ruthless edit of the day - this is what they need to know. Most people, and we have spoken to thousands of readers over the last year or so, they only want 30 minutes, they only have 30 minutes, everyone is time poor nowadays. from Alison Phillips, Editor of New Day

"There has been a massive nuclear bomb gone off in the media world with the advent of the internet, and we have created a newspaper which reflects that and understands that. So, whilst now there is a breaking story and people have got news alerts on their phones all the time, what they quite often want is a ruthless edit of the day - this is what they need to know. Most people, and we have spoken to thousands of readers over the last year or so, they only want 30 minutes, they only have 30 minutes, everyone is time poor nowadays.

Alison Phillips, Editor of New Day

The return of Richard Ashcroft

Mark Savage

Music reporter

PressCopyright: Press

"It's easy for me to drift into two or three years of doing nothing," Richard Ashcroft told BBC 6 Music in 2012 - and he remained true to his word.

But this morning, he emerged from hibernation with a new single and the details of his first album since 2010's United Nations Of Sound.

These People, due out in May, was recorded largely in Ashcroft’s basement home studio and features orchestration from Wil Malone, who worked with Richard on The Verve’s Urban Hymns, as well as his 2000 debut solo album Alone With Everybody.

Have a listen to the lead track, This Is How It Feels, below.

Ashcroft says the album tackles topics such as the Arab Spring uprisings, the war in Syria and the death of a close friend.

Here's his (rather enigmatic) typewritten statement.

PressCopyright: Press

Martin Freeman and Chris O'Dowd earn animation nominations

BBCCopyright: BBC

Actors Martin Freeman and Chris O'Dowd have landed nominations at this year's British Animation Awards.

They are both in the running for best voice performance for their work on Stick Man and Puffin Rock respectively.

Stick Man, Shaun The Sheep: The Movie and Children of the Holocaust will compete for best long form animation.

In other awards news, Oscar hopeful Mad Max: Fury Road won trophies for best period and/or character make-up and for best special make-up effects at the Make-up Artists and Hairstylists Guild awards.

APCopyright: AP

Joe Swash leaves the jump

PACopyright: PA

Former EastEnders actor Joe Swash is the latest injury-plagued celebrity to leave Channel 4's The Jump.

Swash was recruited after several contestants, including Beth Tweddle, Tina Hobley and Rebecca Adlington pulled out due to injury.

He became a victim of the slopes and broke his shoulder during a training session just days after starting.

The injury meant that he was unable to compete in a live moguls challenge and instead lost out to Girls Aloud star Sarah Harding in a ski jump.

Where did the red carpet come from?

BBC Culture

BBC Culture

Getty ImagesCopyright: Getty Images

On Wednesday evening, popstars including Ed Sheeran and Adele will tread on one and just a couple of days later, it will be the turn of stars such as Leonardo DiCaprio and Cate Blanchett.

But when did the red carpet become the ultimate signifier of celebrity?

Apparently it dates back at least 2,500 years.

Lindsay Baker has been investigating for BBC Culture.

Legoland builds 500,000 piece Death Star

Legoland WindsorCopyright: Legoland Windsor

Our eyes are watering at how much this box set would cost you for Christmas.

Staff at Legoland Windsor have put the finishing touches to a 500,000 piece Death Star.

The operation took three days - the piece is a 2.4 metre wide, 3 metre high creation and weighs 860kg.

It will be part of a new Star Wars exhibit at the park.

Legoland WindsorCopyright: Legoland Windsor

All Saints announce first live date

PACopyright: PA

We told you earlier about the V Festival line-up, which was just announced this morning. Nestled in amongst Sia and David Guetta, perhaps surprisingly, was All Saints - the late nineties pop band now on their second reunion. Well, to go with the festival appearance, they've now also announced a live date at Koko in London in April.

This calls for an All Saints timeline.

1997: All Saints 1.0 - Shaznay, Melanie, Nicole and Natalie score number one hits with Pure Shores, Bootie Call and Never Ever and release two top three albums before parting ways in 2000.

2006: All Saints 2.0 - Comeback single Rock Steady is released, which reaches the UK top three. Reunion album Studio 1 fares slightly less well, entering at number 40.

2016: All Saints 3.0 - A second reunion is announced on social media. A V Festival appearance and a live date at Koko in London are confirmed, with a new single One Strike set to premiere on BBC Radio 2 tomorrow.

Benidorm to return for ninth season

Good news for Benidorm fans this morning - we've just heard that the ITV comedy is going into production this month for a ninth series.

It's been drawing 5.8 million viewers per episode this series.

Sherrie Hewson, Tim Healy and Jake Canuso will all return to the cast for the next season.

ITVCopyright: ITV

Kylie Minogue to tie the knot with British actor

PACopyright: PA

Kylie Minogue and her boyfriend Joshua Sasse announced their engagement over the weekend.

The happy couple took out a notice in the Telegraph newspaper.

The 47-year-old star has been going out with the 28-year-old British actor for just six months.

It's thought he may have popped the question over Christmas.

Joshua posted a message of thanks to well-wishers

Read more.

How can a computer write a musical?

Beyond the Fence is the first musical conceived and generated by computer.

It uses an algorithm which factors in the music of hit musicals such as Les Miserables and Crazy For You.

The question is, will humans be entertained?

Country duo hope for Eurovision glory

Darline are a country pop duo - Abby Inez, 20 from Worcester and Càra Beth Beard, 18 from Hertfordshire. Having recently supported The Shires on tour, they are hoping to represent the UK at the 2016 Eurovision Song Contest.

Their song, Until Tomorrow, was co-written by Martine McCutcheon's husband, Jack McManus.

Key lyric: "Hold on to me, like the last leaf on a tree."

Another Eurovision ballad revealed

Mark Savage

Music reporter

And here's the final act hoping to secure your votes and get a ticket to Stockholm for the Eurovision Song Contest.

Karl William Lund, aged 29, is originally from Liverpool and began writing his entry - Miracle - whilst working in Greece as part of a Beatles tribute act.

A slow-burning ballad (aren't they all?) it peddles the traditional Eurovision messages of self-belief and the power of love.

Key lyric: "I want to fly in your arms."

Flack and Murs confirm X Factor exit

Getty ImagesCopyright: Getty Images

Is there an exodus at The X Factor?

Less than a week after Radio 1 breakfast host Nick Grimshaw announced he was leaving the show after one series, now presenters Olly Murs and Caroline Flack have confirmed they are quitting.

Quote Message: This was an incredibly hard decision to make and one I didn’t take lightly as I’ve really enjoyed co-hosting the X Factor with Caroline Flack. It’s been one big adventure and I loved every minute of it but my heart belongs to music and I want to concentrate 100% on making my next album and getting back to performing. from Olly Murs

This was an incredibly hard decision to make and one I didn’t take lightly as I’ve really enjoyed co-hosting the X Factor with Caroline Flack. It’s been one big adventure and I loved every minute of it but my heart belongs to music and I want to concentrate 100% on making my next album and getting back to performing.

Olly Murs

To show there were no hard feelings, Simon Cowell has also released a statement saying it was "fantastic having Olly on the X Factor last year", and described working with him as "great fun".

Simon added that the pair have agreed to work on some other TV projects together in the future.

Olly's presenting style received mixed reviews and he famously messed up an elimination, telling a contestant she was leaving before it was actually announced.

Caroline Flack has also confirmed she's giving up her presenting job:

Quote Message: I have had a brilliant time working on The X Factor over the last few years, and hosting the main show was just fantastic, I made some amazing friends. I'm looking forward to carrying on working with the team over at ITV. from Caroline Flack

I have had a brilliant time working on The X Factor over the last few years, and hosting the main show was just fantastic, I made some amazing friends. I'm looking forward to carrying on working with the team over at ITV.

Caroline Flack

The pair previously presented The Xtra Factor on ITV2 and received a warm response from viewers. They moved over to ITV to front the main programme last year, but had big shoes to fill - as the last presenter, Dermot O'Leary, worked on the show for eight years.

With more and more vacancies opening up on the programme, there are several questions hanging over this year's series - who will replace Nick Grimshaw as a judge, and who will Simon Cowell choose as presenters? Now might be a good time to update your CV.

Former boyband member enters Eurovision

Mark Savage

Music reporter

Ken Bruce has revealed the fourth Eurovision hopeful on his BBC Radio 2 show - and the name might be familiar to fans of moderately successful 1990s boybands.

Matthew James was part of Bad Boys Inc, who scored a few minor hits in 1993 and 1994.

His song, A Better Man, revisits the slick pop ballads of that era (the writer's previous credits include the Backstreet Boys) but is too generic to really catch fire.

Key lyric: "You make me want to be a better man."
